metadata.case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957 and Petitions under Article 32 (Newspaper Establishments v. Union of India)
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957; Petitions Nos. 91, 99-101, 103, 116-118 of 1957

facts.text: Newspaper industry in India originally started as individual newspapers founded by leaders but developed into profit-making industry with big industrialists investing and combines controlling several newspapers.
Working journalists agitated for inquiry into wages, salaries, dearness allowance, retirement benefits, leave and conditions of service by impartial agency.
Uttar Pradesh Government appointed committee on June 18, 1947 to inquire into conditions of newspaper employees.
Central Provinces Berar Government appointed Inquiry Committee on March 27, 1948 to examine conditions of newspaper industry including emoluments, leave, provident fund.
Committees made reports on March 31, 1949 and March 27, 1948 with recommendations.
Press Commission appointed on September 23, 1952 under Chairmanship of Shri Justice G. S. Rajadhyaksha; submitted report on July 14, 1954.
Press Commission found out of 137 concerns, 59 returned profits, 68 losses; industry profit about 6 lakhs on 7 crores capital, less than 1%.
Press Commission recommended minimum wage Rs. 125 + Rs. 25 dearness allowance; division of localities for differential cost of living.
Working Journalists Industrial Disputes Act, 1955 (1 of 1955) passed on March 12, 1955 applying Industrial Disputes Act to working journalists.
Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955) received assent on December 20, 1955.
Central Government constituted Wage Board on May 2, 1956 under s.8; Chairman Shri H. Divatia; members representing employers and journalists.
Working Journalists Wage Board Rules, 1956 published July 30, 1956; provided for decision by majority.
Wage Board decision published in Gazette of India Extraordinary Part II, Section 3 dated May 11, 1957.
Appeals by special leave from Wage Board decision; hearings Dec 1957 and Jan 1958.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 is ultra vires as it infringes fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14 and 32.
Whether the Wage Board constituted under the Act exercises legislative, quasi-judicial or judicial functions.
Whether the decision of the Wage Board is illegal, void or ultra vires the Act.
Whether the Act is discriminatory under Article 14 and imposes unreasonable restrictions on freedom to carry on business under Article 19(1)(g).

petitioner_arguments.text: Working Journalists Act, 1955 ultra vires as infringes Arts. 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, 32; freedom of speech includes freedom of Press and means to exercise it.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 19(1)(a); Ramesh Thapar v. State of Madras; Brij Bhusan v. State of Delhi

petitioner_arguments.text: Act fixes salaries disabling running of press, impedes freedom of expression; not saved by Art. 19(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning; Minnesota Ex Rel. Olson

petitioner_arguments.text: Violates Art. 19(1)(g) by unreasonable restraint on business; no capacity to pay as criterion.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Chintaman Rao v. State of MP; State of Madras v. V.G. Row

petitioner_arguments.text: Criteria in s.9(1) for wages relevant only for minimum wages; subjective satisfaction arbitrary.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Thakur Raghbir Singh v. Court of Wards

petitioner_arguments.text: No procedure laid down for Wage Board; disregards audi alteram partem; quasi-judicial functions.
Discriminatory under Art.14: favours working journalists over others; singles out newspaper employers.
Wage Board decision illegal: ultra vires Act, no reasons, reconstitution invalid, no capacity to pay considered, classification on gross revenue erroneous.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mohd Yasin v. Town Area Committee

petitioner_arguments.text: Retrospective operation, scales for 3 years exceed powers; violates natural justice.

respondent_arguments.text: Act does not infringe Arts.19(1)(a),19(1)(g),14,32; Wage Board performs legislative function, not judicial.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras; pith and substance doctrine

respondent_arguments.text: Regulates conditions of service, not directly freedom of speech; reasonable under Art.19(6).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala

respondent_arguments.text: s.9(1) criteria followed; capacity to pay region-wise considered; scales permissible.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Report of Committee on Fair Wages; Art.43

respondent_arguments.text: No audi alteram partem for legislative acts; classification reasonable as journalists distinct class.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar; Art.14

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions like gratuity, hours reasonable; s.12,17 not discriminatory.
Gross revenue basis for classification valid; no need for unit-wise capacity.

court_reasoning.text: History of events leading to Act: from state committees, Press Commission report, to enactment of Working Journalists Industrial Disputes Act 1955 and main Act 1955.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act designed to regulate conditions of service based on Press Commission recommendations.

court_reasoning.text: Detailed provisions of Act: definitions, application of Industrial Disputes Act with modifications, retrenchment, gratuity, hours, leave, Wage Board constitution under s.8-11.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wage Board to fix rates considering cost of living, prevalent wages, regional circumstances.

court_reasoning.text: Press Commission recommended minimum wage but word 'minimum' dropped in Bill; Act provides for Wage Board with equal representatives.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fixation of rates of wages includes scales.

key_quotes.text: "The guarantee of an abstract freedom of expression would be meaningless unless it contemplated and included in its ambit all the means necessary for the practical application of the freedom."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of Art.19(1)(a) for Press freedom

key_quotes.text: "If a newspaper could not afford to pay the minimum wage to the employee which would enable him to live decently and with dignity, that newspaper had no business to exist."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Press Commission view on minimum wage

key_quotes.text: "Let the word minimum be dropped and let it be a proper wage board which will look into this question in all its aspects."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent_counsel
